They're reinventing the wheel (again!).
The home computer industry had this one nailed, with the original IBM PC. The keyboard was "clicky" to give positive feedback. The clicks came not from a mechanical clicker in each key but from the PC's rudimentary speaker. With each key-press you knew whether the key had actually closed the connection. It sounded almost like a typewriter key striking paper, but unlike a typewriter you could adjust the volume.
Didn't last long. Clone makers found they could imitate the experience more cheaply by building a mechanical click into the keys. As computer users grew in number, we who understood the purpose of the click and were willing to pay more for positive feedback, were outnumbered by the clueless hoard. For a brief period, clicky keyboards were valued over quiet ones and their pointless noise, which couldn't be turned down or shut off, was widely referred to as "feedback". Eventually people realized that a mechanical click from their keyboard did NOT confirm that their key-press had registered, and keyboards became silent by popular demand. Genuine key-press feedback, via the speaker, was abandoned by the PC industry because too few users understood what it was for.
You wrote, "smartphones, like my (beloved) iPhone give no tactile feedback. Rather the user must look at the keyboard to confirm that the correct key has been touched." But the phones can at least be optioned to give audible feedback that SOME key was touched. Apple provides that for iPhone keypads; do they provide an equivalent for their computer keyboards? (I expect they don't, or they wouldn't think they need to invent compressed-air feedback.)
